summary.text_en: James Watt radically improved the 1712 Newcomen engine. His key innovation, the 'Separate Condenser' (patented 1769, commercial 1776), allowed the main cylinder to remain 'always hot' while the condenser remained 'always cold'. This (and later innovations like the 'double-acting' piston and 'parallel motion' linkage) increased the engine's fuel efficiency by over 3x and allowed it to produce smooth 'rotary motion'. This finally enabled steam to power factories, mills, and locomotives, truly igniting the Industrial Revolution.
key_points_en: Enabled steam to create 'Rotary Motion' for the first time
Commercialized in partnership with Matthew Boulton

story.text_en: While repairing a model Newcomen engine in 1764, Watt realized its critical flaw: it was incredibly wasteful to constantly heat the cylinder with steam, only to immediately chill it with cold water. His flash of genius (in 1765) was: why not condense the steam in a *separate, permanently cold* container (the condenser)? This allowed the main cylinder to remain *permanently hot*. This simple separation was a massive leap in thermal efficiency and is the core idea of modern engines.

fun_facts.text_en: To sell his engine to mine owners, Watt needed a way to describe its power. He invented the unit of 'Horsepower' to compare his engine to the horses it was replacing. We still use it for cars today.
In recognition of his monumental contribution to the Industrial Revolution, the SI unit of power is named the 'Watt'.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Newcomen's engine (`newcomen_engine_1712`) was like a single room that you used as *both* a furnace and a freezer. You'd heat it up, then throw ice in, then heat it up again... a total waste of fuel.
Watt's improvement was to build *two rooms*. One room (the cylinder) was 'always the furnace' (hot), and a second room (the condenser) was 'always the freezer' (cold), connected by a pipe. This stopped the engine from wasting heat, made it vastly more efficient, and allowed it to finally leave the coal mine and power factories and trains.

applications.text_en: The efficiency and rotary motion of the Watt engine were the necessary prerequisites for the later invention of the steam locomotive and steamboat.

impact.text_en: The James Watt steam engine was the *true* engine of the Industrial Revolution. Newcomen's engine started it, but Watt's engine scaled it. It liberated humanity from dependence on natural power (water, wind, muscle) and provided controllable, cheap, massive power, fundamentally reshaping human production, transport, economics, and society.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Newcomen's Atmospheric Engine (which served as the 'prototype' that Watt was given to repair and improve)
Joseph Black (his discovery of 'latent heat' revealed to Watt *how much* energy the Newcomen engine was wasting)

influenced.contribution_en: Sadi Carnot (his 'Reflections on the Motive Power of Fire' was the theory created to explain the efficiency limits of Watt's engine)
George Stephenson (his 'Rocket' locomotive was a direct application of Watt's rotative steam engine)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Watt transformed the steam engine from an inefficient mine pump into the efficient, universal power source that drove the entire Industrial Revolution.

quiz.question_en: What was James Watt's single most critical and important improvement to the Newcomen steam engine?
options_en: He was the first person to use steam
quiz.explanation_en: Newcomen's engine wasted immense fuel by heating and cooling the same cylinder. Watt's genius was adding a 'separate condenser', which allowed the main cylinder to stay hot at all times, multiplying the fuel efficiency.
